title: I‚Äôm a brain scientist. These are five signs of cognitive decline ‚Äì and how to delay it
description: Ben Parris is a professor of cognition and cognitive neuroscience in Bournemouth University‚Äôs School of Psychology. He is also co-founder of the university‚Äôs Interdisciplinary Neuroscience Research Centre
fullText:
Ben Parris is a professor of cognition and cognitive neuroscience in Bournemouth University‚Äôs School of Psychology. He is also co-founder of the university‚Äôs Interdisciplinary Neuroscience Research Centre

A decline in your cognitive health is something that can creep up on you. It‚Äôs not like a bad back or dodgy knee, which will give you plenty of gyp as soon as there is a problem. You may suddenly find that you‚Äôre not quite as mentally sharp as you once were.

You may notice that it becomes harder to hold conversations, remember phone numbers and do everyday tasks such as go to the shops. That‚Äôs a result of your frontal lobe beginning to waste away, which happens to all of us as we age, though at different rates.

This part of the brain is located just behind our forehead and is home to our executive functions ‚Äì our ability to plan, organise, focus and generally interact with the world around us. It‚Äôs different from dementia, though that disease speeds up the process.

While the frontal lobe does eventually deteriorate, as a professor and researcher who studies cognitive decline, I have seen it remain in good nick in people in their 60s and beyond.

The key to keeping your mental abilities sharp as you age starts with noticing when the frontal lobe is shrinking. If you‚Äôre aware, there are things you can do to slow it down. So here are the signs it‚Äôs happening to you, and what you can do about it. I‚Äôve also compiled a series of tests so that you can test how well your brain is ageing, which you can access below.

One of the first signs of a decline in your cognitive health can be struggling to switch between tasks, such as cooking a meal while also holding a conversation with someone.

You might notice that you struggle to respond to someone‚Äôs comment, as you‚Äôre still thinking about what to do next in your recipe.

There is a loosening of the sharpness that was once there. The tasks bleed together, you‚Äôre not able to focus and it takes you a bit of time to adjust.

This signals a problem with your cognitive flexibility, which is the ability to switch between different tasks and remain focused. This represents one of the more difficult tasks that we engage in on a daily basis, so it can be the first ability that you notice is deteriorating.

In extreme cases, people can be stirring a pot and as they turn around to talk to someone, they are still doing the action of stirring but without the spoon in their hand.

We can all jumble up words at times, especially if we‚Äôre tired or distracted. However, if you catch yourself regularly skipping over words, it could be a sign of cognitive decline.

For example, instead of saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just going to pop to the shops‚Äù, you might come out with ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just shops‚Äù.

It can be a sign that there is a problem with your response inhibition, which is a cognitive function located in your frontal lobe. It is a skill we need for focus and to block out irrelevant information.

When you skip words like this, it means that your brain failed to inhibit (or block out) the last word in the sentence until it was time to say it. It‚Äôs a form of language breakdown that can be an early sign of dementia.

Regularly mixing up related words is another sign that your cognition isn‚Äôt in peak condition.

For example, if you want to say the word ‚Äúfork‚Äù, it should be at the forefront of your mind but, when there is a problem with response inhibition, related words such as ‚Äúspoon‚Äù and ‚Äúknife‚Äù can also float to the surface.

If this part of our cognitive function continues to deteriorate, you may say words that become increasingly distant from the word you meant to say, for example ‚Äúplate‚Äù or even ‚Äútrain‚Äù instead of ‚Äúfork‚Äù. This is a sign that there is misfiring going on in the brain.

The frequency with which this occurs and the distance from the word you intended to say can be used to determine the severity of cognitive decline.

If you realise that you need to nip to the shop for some milk, your brain quickly comes up with a plan. Where is the nearest shop? How will you get there? Do you have a way of paying?

With good cognitive health, this requires little effort and you may not give these questions a second thought. However, if one of these components goes wrong ‚Äì for example, you forget a means of payment ‚Äì it signals a failure in working memory, which is our ability to maintain and manipulate information.

As you were leaving the house, you failed to maintain one of the key components of the task. Such mental slips become more common as we age and our frontal lobes atrophy.

If this happens occasionally and is not increasing in frequency, it‚Äôs nothing to worry about. I have been known to drive to the supermarket and walk home, forgetting that I‚Äôve left the car as I‚Äôve been busy thinking about other things.

However, if it happens more and more often, you might want to consider seeing your GP. It could be an early sign of dementia.

Forgetting what you need from the shop, and struggling to find the items you want to buy, are signs of cognitive decline.

You rely on your short-term memory to remember what you need from the shop and your spatial memory (the ability to understand where you are in relation to your surroundings) to be able to find the products you need.

If this part of your cognitive health is deteriorating, you may find yourself walking up and down the same aisles many times, as you‚Äôve forgotten which you‚Äôve already been down.

One famous study took patients to a shopping centre and gave them a list of items to buy, such as milk and a newspaper. Those suffering from cognitive decline walked up and down multiple times, getting the items in an illogical way, following an incoherent path.

If you are experiencing any of these symptoms and it is significantly affecting your ability to continue with life as normal, or you have noticed that they are getting worse, I would recommend going to your GP.

It‚Äôs also worth booking an appointment with your doctor if a loved one is concerned about your cognitive health, even if you are not, as you could be experiencing anosognosia, which is a lack of awareness of your own cognitive decline. This is a common problem.

While these symptoms could be a sign of cognitive decline or dementia, they could also be caused by a stroke or tumour. The earlier you see your GP, the easier it is to treat.

If concerned, your doctor should refer you to the neuropsychology clinic at your local hospital. There, you will probably complete a series of memory tests, such as the ‚ÄúStroop task‚Äù and the Corsi block-tapping test, and have an MRI to look for shrinkage in the frontal lobe, which would indicate dementia, or lesions, which may be evidence of a stroke.

There are no hidden secrets in terms of maintaining cognitive health. As far as we‚Äôre aware, it‚Äôs the same recommendations as for maintaining bodily health.

Diet and exercise are the two most important pillars to focus on for your brain.

Following a healthy diet ‚Äì which includes plenty of green leafy vegetables, fish, nuts and berries ‚Äì has been shown to slow cognitive decline, which is thought to be because these foods contain nutrients such as folate and omega-3 fatty acids.

Weight-training twice a week has been linked to less brain shrinkage and better performance on memory tests, while cardio improves blood flow, including to the brain, promoting the development of new brain cells and protecting the organ against inflammation.

I always recommend cutting back on alcohol ‚Äì and only drink a few times a year myself ‚Äì as research has shown that it causes shrinkage in parts of the brain important for memory, and poorer performance on cognitive tests. I‚Äôd also recommend quitting drinking alcohol alone, as the only benefits thought to come from drinking is if it gets you out socialising.

It‚Äôs possible that the deterioration of our frontal lobe happens, or is sped up, due to a lack of use, and challenging your brain has been linked with delaying cognitive decline. This could mean learning a new instrument or language, reading difficult books, doing calculations in your head instead of on your phone calculator, completing puzzles, and even watching quiz shows. They can all play a role in keeping your brain younger.

Spending time in nature has been linked to better working memory, while holding conversations, and socialising has been shown to keep our cognitive health better for longer. Whether it‚Äôs having a conversation or making plans to meet loved ones, you‚Äôre working those cognitive muscles.

title: SCOTUS Justice‚Äôs Blistering Dissent Vindicated by Bombshell Study
description: A new study has bolstered a scathing dissent from liberal Supreme Court Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson that warned the court appeared to favor the rich. The study, published Monday by the National Bureau of Economic Research, investigated whether the Supreme Court has contributed to rising income inequality by ruling in favor of policies that favor wealthy parties. Its authors‚Äîtwo academics from Columbia University in New York and one from Yale University‚Äîfound that in cases pitting the rich agai
fullText:
A new study has bolstered a scathing dissent from liberal Supreme Court Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson that warned the court appeared to favor the rich.

The study, published Monday by the National Bureau of Economic Research, investigated whether the Supreme Court has contributed to rising income inequality by ruling in favor of policies that favor wealthy parties.

Its authors‚Äîtwo academics from Columbia University in New York and one from Yale University‚Äîfound that in cases pitting the rich against the poor, Republican appointees were far more likely than their Democratic colleagues to side with the wealthier party.

Back in 1953, Democratic and Republican appointees were statistically indistinguishable on the issue, with justices appointed by members of both parties favoring the rich in 45 percent of cases on average.

The average Democratic justice cast a ‚Äúpro-rich‚Äù vote‚Äîwhich was defined as a vote that would directly shift resources to the party that was more likely to be wealthy, including votes that supported businesses over consumers or workers‚Äîjust 35 percent of the time.

‚ÄúThe results reveal a steady increase in polarization, mostly due to Republican appointees whose decisions rise from about 50 percent pro-rich share to a 70 percent pro-rich share over the course of 70 years,‚Äù the study‚Äôs authors, Andrea Prat, a Columbia economics professor, Jacob Spitz, a Columbia PhD student, Fiona Scott Morton, a Yale economics professor, and wrote.

The findings also supported a June dissent authored by Brown Jackson, according to The New York Times.

The justices held 7-2 that oil and gas companies had legal standing to challenge California‚Äôs environmental regulations requiring automakers to produce more electric vehicles and fewer gasoline-powered ones.

‚ÄúThis case gives fodder to the unfortunate perception that moneyed interests enjoy an easier road to relief in this Court than ordinary citizens,‚Äù Brown Jackson wrote. ‚ÄúI worry that the fuel industry‚Äôs gain comes at a reputational cost for this Court, which is already viewed by many as being overly sympathetic to corporate interests.‚Äù

That perception could be contributing to an overall drop in public confidence in the court, according to the Times. The Daily Beast has reached out to the Supreme Court for comment.

The court‚Äôs favorability rating has plunged by 22 points over the past five years, from 70 percent in 2020 to a near-record low 48 percent late last year, the Pew Research Center reported in September.

And although a vast majority of Americans, or 86 percent, think the justices should be non-partisan, 56 percent said the justices were doing only a fair or poor job of keeping their political views out of their legal decision-making.

title: ‚ÄòDances with Wolves‚Äô actor Nathan Chasing Horse disrupts court week before sex abuse trial
description: Nathan Chasing Horse, the former ‚ÄúDances with Wolves‚Äù actor accused of sexual abuse, was temporarily thrown out of court Monday after he disrupted proceedings with demands he be allowed to fire his defense attorney a week before trial.  Judge Jessica Peterson in Las Vegas ordered his jury trial to proceed next week as planned.  Prosecutors allege he used his reputation as a spiritual leader and healer to take advantage of Native American women and girls over two decades.
fullText:
LAS VEGAS (AP) ‚Äî Nathan Chasing Horse, the former ‚ÄúDances with Wolves‚Äù actor accused of sexual abuse, was temporarily thrown out of court Monday after he disrupted proceedings with demands he be allowed to fire his defense attorney a week before trial.

Judge Jessica Peterson in Las Vegas ordered his jury trial to proceed next week as planned.

Chasing Horse has pleaded not guilty to 21 charges, including allegations that he sexually assaulted women and girls and that he filmed himself sexually abusing a girl younger than 14. Prosecutors allege he used his reputation as a spiritual leader and healer to take advantage of Native American women and girls over two decades.

Peterson ordered him removed from court Monday for trying to speak over her. He argued that his attorney, Craig Mueller, did not come to visit him and did not file timely. He asked that a public defender who previously represented him be his attorney.

Mueller, a private defense attorney, told the court his client was ready and privately told the judge that one of his investigators had visited with Chasing Horse. He declined to comment to The Associated Press.

Best known for portraying the character Smiles A Lot in the 1990 movie ‚ÄúDances with Wolves,‚Äù Chasing Horse was born on the Rosebud Reservation in South Dakota, which is home to the Sicangu Sioux, one of the seven tribes of the Lakota nation.

After starring in the Oscar-winning film, according to prosecutors, Chasing Horse began propping himself up as a self-proclaimed Lakota medicine man while traveling around North America to perform healing ceremonies. When he was arrested in 2023, he was living in a North Las Vegas house with his five wives, according to prosecutors.

The case sent shock waves across Indian Country. The original indictment was dismissed in 2024 after the Nevada Supreme Court ruled prosecutors abused the grand jury process when they provided a definition of grooming as evidence without any expert testimony. However, the court left open the possibility of charges being refiled, and a new indictment was brought later that year.

Prosecutors claim Chasing Horse led a cult called The Circle, and his followers believed he could speak with spirits. His victims went to him for medical help, according to a transcript from a grand jury hearing.

Prosecutors expect the trial to last three weeks. It is scheduled to begin Monday.

title: After Maduro capture, Trump's tough talk evokes a return to the days of American imperialism
description: President Donald Trump hasn't minced words about the larger message he's trying to send the world with the U.S. military raid to capture Nicol√°s Maduro and spirit the deposed Venezuelan leader and his wife to the United States to face federal drug trafficking charges.  ‚ÄúAmerican dominance in the Western Hemisphere," Trump declared following Maduro's capture, ‚Äúwill never be questioned again.‚Äù  In the days since the audacious raid, Trump and his team have doubled down on the notion that the new focus on American preeminence in the hemisphere is here to stay.
fullText:
WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî President Donald Trump hasn't minced words about the larger message he's trying to send the world with the U.S. military raid to capture Nicol√°s Maduro and spirit the deposed Venezuelan leader and his wife to the United States to face federal drug trafficking charges.

‚ÄúAmerican dominance in the Western Hemisphere," Trump declared following Maduro's capture, ‚Äúwill never be questioned again.‚Äù

In the days since the audacious raid, Trump and his team have doubled down on the notion that the new focus on American preeminence in the hemisphere is here to stay. He also held up Maduro's capture to make the case to neighbors to get in line or potentially face consequences.

Trump‚Äôs rhetoric harkens back to the muscular talk of the late 19th and early 20th centuries when American presidents deployed the military for territorial and resource conquests, including to Cuba, Puerto Rico, Hawaii, Honduras, Panama, Nicaragua, Mexico, Haiti and the Dominican Republic.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs been periods, Vietnam and Iraq, which have evoked questions about a return to American imperialism, but the U.S. leaders‚Äô messages in those periods were cloaked in talk of democracy. The way Trump is talking about it is something we haven‚Äôt seen in a very long time.‚Äù said Edward Frantz, a historian at the University of Indianapolis.

In the aftermath of the operation, Trump's tough talk has been been directed at titular allies in Greenland ‚Äî where he renewed calls for the U.S. to take over the Danish territory for national security reasons ‚Äî and Mexico. Trump says America's southern neighbor needs to ‚Äúget their act together‚Äù fighting drug cartels.

Trump has also warned that longtime adversary Cuba is ‚Äúgoing down‚Äù now that Maduro, who has provided deeply discounted oil to the economically isolated government in Havana, has been deposed. And the president has heightened anxiety with Venezuela's neighbor, telling reporters that a military operation in Colombia ‚Äî the epicenter of global cocaine production ‚Äî "sounds good to me."

The Republican president has also said his administration will ‚Äúrun‚Äù Venezuela policy and threatened the country's new leader, interim President Delcy Rodr√≠guez, with an outcome worse than Maduro's if she does not ‚Äúdo what‚Äôs right.‚Äù He's made plain that he expects Caracas to open its vast oil reserves to U.S. energy companies, further igniting speculation about American overreach.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to have our very large United States oil companies, the biggest anywhere in the world, go in, spend billions of dollars, fix the badly broken infrastructure ‚Äî the oil infrastructure ‚Äî and start making money for the country,‚Äù Trump said over the weekend.

The Venezuela incursion has split Latin America, with Trump‚Äëaligned leaders mostly from the right applauding the ouster, and non‚Äëaligned leaders condemning it on sovereignty grounds. It's sharpened concerns that Trump might actually be serious about his desire to annex Greenland as well.

Leaning on Monroe Doctrine, Trump puts neighbors on edge

Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen warned Monday that Trump would mark the undoing of the transatlantic military alliance, NATO, if he attempts to follow through on his assertion that the U.S. ‚Äúabsolutely‚Äù needs to take over Greenland for national security reasons. The alliance, which includes the U.S. and Denmark, has been a linchpin of post-World War II security.

‚ÄúIf the United States chooses to attack another NATO country militarily, then everything stops,‚Äù Frederiksen told Danish broadcaster TV2.

In the early part of the 20th century, American leaders repeatedly turned to the Monroe Doctrine, a foundational U.S. foreign policy document authored by the nation's fifth president, which had been aimed at opposing European meddling in the Western Hemisphere.

Now, Trump too is leaning on the doctrine to justify U.S. intervention in Venezuela and threaten action around the hemisphere in the name of protecting the safety and welfare of Americans.

‚ÄúTrump's rhetoric conjures up images of Teddy Roosevelt and gunboat diplomacy. The rhetoric is a return to a pre-Great War era,‚Äù Frantz said, referring to the 26th president's intercessions in unstable Caribbean and Central American economies as well as his backing of Panama's secession from Colombia in the name of the U.S. national interest.

Just weeks before the ouster of Maduro, Trump rolled out a long-awaited National Security Strategy that had some disparate elements that seemed to be at odds with each other.

On one hand, Trump, who has long eschewed America's role in foreign wars, asserted that the administration would have a ‚Äúpredisposition to non-interventionism.‚Äù But the strategy document also made clear that the administration would push ‚Äúto restore American preeminence in the Western Hemisphere.‚Äù

With the ouster of Maduro, the administration has clearly doubled down on the latter.

‚ÄúThis is the Western Hemisphere," Secretary of State Marco Rubio said in an appearance on NBC's ‚ÄúMeet the Press‚Äù on Sunday. "This is where we live ‚Äî and we‚Äôre not going to allow the Western Hemisphere to be a base of operation for adversaries, competitors and rivals of the United States.‚Äù

The capture of Maduro and Trump's rhetoric could certainly be a level-setting moment for global leaders as they consider what may lay ahead in the final three years of Trump's second term.

At an emergency U.N. Security Council meeting Monday, Colombian Ambassador Leonor Zalabata Torres said the raid in Venezuela was reminiscent of ‚Äúthe worst interference in our area in the past.‚Äù

‚ÄúDemocracy cannot be defended or promoted through violence and coercion, and it cannot be superseded, either, by economic interests,‚Äù said Zalabata Torres, whose country requested the meeting.

At the same time, Democrats are questioning whether Trump's actions have created a permission structure for Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has designs of capturing further territory from neighboring Ukraine, and Chinese President Xi Jinping, who has vowed to annex the self-ruled island of Taiwan.

‚ÄúWhat the president's done in this case has essentially given Putin and Xi Jinping a hall pass," said Sen. Angus King, I-Maine, in an appearance on CNN.

The Russians, for their part, have condemned Trump's action in Venezuela. Ambassador Vassily Nebenzia, the country's U.N. envoy, said the world body ‚Äúcannot allow the United States to proclaim itself as some kind of a supreme judge‚Äù to the world.

AP writers Jennifer Peltz and Farnoush Amiri at the United Nations contributed to this report.

title: Iconic BBQ grill chain closes most of its restaurants
description: Dozens, maybe hundreds of restaurants have tried to copy the Chipotle model of offering customized meals made live in front of customers by workers on a "make line." In theory, it's a simple way to offer fresh food that's customizable based on what the customer wants. The problem is that the devil ...
fullText:
Dozens, maybe hundreds of restaurants have tried to copy the Chipotle model of offering customized meals made live in front of customers by workers on a "make line." In theory, it's a simple way to offer fresh food that's customizable based on what the customer wants.

The problem is that the devil is in the details. Chipotle has figured out how to deliver a product customers want in an efficient and cost-effective style.

In fact, the Mexican chain has actually created a fast-food product that consumers value enough to pay more for it than what they typically spend.

Higher price than fast food: A Chipotle burrito or bowl averages $12 to $14, compared with $7 to $11 for a McDonald‚Äôs or Taco Bell combo, according to Fox9.

Competitive in fast casual: Chipotle meals are about 30 to 40% cheaper than premium fast-casual rivals like Sweetgreen or Cava, according to Restaurant Dive.

Cost drivers: Prices reflect fresh ingredients, sustainable sourcing, labor, and generous portion sizes, which differentiate it from typical fast-food operations, reported Meals By Andy.

Essentially, the Mexican chain has built something that's better than fast food without the expense of being a traditional sit-down fast-casual restaurant with table service.

"Chipotle Mexican Grill is a category-defining fast casual brand that turns a focused menu and made-to-order assembly line into speed, personalization, and consistent quality. Its business model pairs culinary credibility with operational discipline, using a streamlined kitchen and limited SKUs to drive high throughput and attractive unit economics," according to Latterly.com.

"The result is a differentiated value proposition that blends premium ingredients, transparent preparation, and convenience in restaurant and through digital pickup and delivery."

It's easy to see why restaurant operators would want to copy that model, but the struggles of one chain, Genghis Grill, show exactly how hard it is to duplicate what Chipotle created.

When Genghis Grill launched in 1998, it was a variation on the traditional Mongolian BBQ Grill model. It was a build-your-own-bowl model using a per-bowl rather than all-you-can-eat format.

Customers select raw ingredients, proteins, vegetables, sauces, noodles, and spice from the Fresh Bar.

They place everything into a large bowl.

The bowl is then handed to a chef at the grill, who stir-fries the ingredients on a large circular flat-top grill in front of the customer.

I visited the chain for lunch in a Texas mall back in the 2010s and liked that I could customize my bowl, while not having to pay an all-you-can-eat price. At dinner, I may have opted for an AYCE version of the same concept, but getting exactly what I wanted at an affordable price made for an excellent lunch offering.

title: Officials seize multiple cars with illegal devices in major crackdown: 'A serious danger to the lives of everyone on the road'
description: "We will not stop implementing strict laws."
fullText:
Officials in the Philippines recently confiscated a handful of cars that had been modified into racing cars, sharing details of the crackdown on Facebook and sparking conversation about the dangers of illegal modifications and street racing.

The Land Transportation Office in the Calabarzon region seized six Honda Civics that had been illegally modified and were allegedly being used for street racing in Batangas City.

News of the crackdown quickly spread, with the altered cars missing safety components, having "improvised plates," and racing-style alterations that made them unsafe for public roads.

According to authorities, the vehicles violated multiple traffic laws, including operating without registration, using defective or illegal accessories, and failing to meet basic safety requirements such as proper headlights, mufflers, bumpers, and mirrors.

"The illegal modification being done to these vehicles, especially if they are used for illegal racing, is not only a violation of the law but a serious danger to the lives of everyone on the road," LTO Chief Assistant Secretary Markus Lacanilao said in a statement, as reported by the Daily Tribune.

Modified cars with exposed parts, loud exhaust systems, and missing safety features have become a common sight in some areas ‚Äî often celebrated online but simultaneously feared by pedestrians and everyday drivers.

Beyond safety risks, illegal street racing increases noise pollution, contributes to road damage, and puts unnecessary strain on emergency services ‚Äî all while endangering people who never consented to take part. On top of that, while some modifications can be beneficial ‚Äî even eco-friendly ‚Äî many modified vehicles burn more fuel, creating more pollution and contributing to poorer air quality and human health issues.

"We will not stop implementing strict laws ‚Äî all vehicles used in such illegal activities, traffic violations, regardless of type or class, will be apprehended without bias," Lacanilao added. "Road safety is the LTO's primary priority, and we are ready to take steps to prevent avoidable incidents."

Click your choice to see results and speak your mind.
